questions.text: Which of the following is the primary function of the exocrine cells?
questions.solution:
• THE EXOCRINE PANCREAS constitutes 80% to 85% of the organ and is composed of acinar cells.
  • These cells secrete proenzymes (trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, procarboxypeptidase) and digestive enzymes into the duodenum to break down food. (Choice C)
  • To assist in food digestion by releasing a secretion rich in bicarbonate, which helps to neutralize the acidic environment created in stomach. (Choice D)
  • The ENDOCRINE PANCREAS (LANGERHANS ISLETS) FUNCTION:-
  • To secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream and reach to the organ (choice A)
  • To monitor blood sugar levels

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The primary function of the exocrine pancreas is to secrete digestive enzymes (e.g., trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen) into the duodenum to aid in food digestion. It also releases bicarbonate to neutralize stomach acid. The endocrine pancreas, in contrast, secretes hormones like insulin directly into the bloodstream.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the Pancreas?
questions.solution:
• The pancreas forms from two separate buds or anlagen, which later rotate and fuse.
  • The ventral bud, which appears as a part of the developing hepatic duct, forms the posterior and inferior parts of the head and the uncinate process
  • The larger dorsal bud, which develops from the other side of the foregut and extends into the dorsal mesentery, forms the body, tail, and anterior part of the head (choice A)
  • The normal adult pancreas has a dual composition.
    • THE EXOCRINE COMPONENT:-
      • It is made of lobular units of acini, which comprise 80% or more of the gland.
      • They empty into ducts of increasingly larger size that finally merge into the main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) and the accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini).
      • Normally, the Wirsung and Santorini ducts are joined by numerous anastomotic connections; when this is not the case, and the duct of Santorini constitutes the principal drainage for the organ, the condition known as PANCREAS DIVISUM (Choice C)
      • Acinar cells and centroacinar cells
    • THE ENDOCRINE COMPONENT of the pancreas is mainly represented by the Langerhans islets. (Choice D)
      • These constitute 1%-2% of the adult pancreas but a much larger proportion (~20%) of the organ at the time of birth.
      • Types of cells:- B cells, A cells, D cells, PP cells

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

The pancreas develops from two buds: the ventral bud forms the posterior and inferior parts of the head and uncinate process, while the dorsal bud forms the body, tail, and anterior part of the head. The pancreas lacks a distinct capsule. Pancreas divisum occurs when the duct of Santorini primarily drains the pancreas, instead of merging with the duct of Wirsung. The exocrine pancreas, which makes up the majority, consists of acini and ducts, while the endocrine pancreas, containing Langerhans islets, represents 1-2% of the adult pancreas.

questions.text: Which one is true about the annular pancreas?
questions.solution:
ANNULAR PANCREAS

  • A rare embryologic abnormality
  • The ventral primordium of the pancreas fails to rotate properly (choice A)
  • It Can be seen by itself or in combination with other congenital abnormalities of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • F>M
  • Associated with Down syndrome
  • Grossly, there is Encirclement of the duodenum by pancreatic parenchyma, (choice C) which may lead to constriction of the duodenal lumen.
  • The duct in the annular pancreas originates anteriorly and courses to the right over the duodenum and then posteriorly and to the left behind the duodenum, passing near the common duct and finally joining the main pancreatic duct.
  • It is not associated with diabetes (choice B)

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

The annular pancreas is a rare embryologic abnormality where the ventral primordium of the pancreas fails to rotate properly. This condition results in the encirclement of the duodenum by pancreatic parenchyma, which may lead to duodenal obstruction. It is more common in males and associated with Down syndrome. This condition is not typically linked to diabetes.

questions.text: A male patient aged 56 years with a history of smoking, presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, obstructive jaundice. The CT scan of abdomen shows a mass present in the head of the pancreas. And the microscopic features are shown in the following image. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
INTRADUCTAL PAPILLARY MUCINOUS NEOPLASM (IPMN) (choice B)

  • It is a distinct type of intraductal pancreatic tumor that has been defined and segregated from other neoplasms of this organ (particularly Mucinous cystic neoplasms- MCN)
  • Grossly - intraductal location
  • Microscopically - the formation of papillary epithelial projections and the production of abundant intraluminal mucin that ultimately leads to dilatation of the ducts.
  • Most common - in the head of the pancreas
  • Although it may involve any part of the ductal system. The tumor may involve the main pancreatic duct, branch ducts, or both
  • Can be multicentric.

PANCREATOBLASTOMA:- (Choice A)

  • The most common form of pancreatic neoplasia in childhood, accounting for 25% of pancreatic tumors in the first 10 years of life, there is a slight male predominance.
  • Can be associated with the Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and with familial adenomatous polyposis of the colon.

LYMPHOMA:- (Choice D) - There is no lymphoid population in the given image.

PANCREATIC NEUROENDOCRINE NEOPLASM:- (choice C)

  • It can be Well-differentiated NET or poorly differentiated NEC.
  • Endocrine tumors account for 5% all pancreatic malignancies
  • Mostly seen in adults

Microscopically, these tumors are usually composed of small, Relatively uniform cuboidal cells with centrally located nuclei and acidophilic or amphophilic, finely granular cytoplasm

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm (IPMN) is a pancreatic tumor characterized by intraductal location, papillary projections, and abundant mucin production, leading to duct dilation. It is most commonly found in the head of the pancreas and can be multicentric. Pancreatoblastoma occurs in children, while pancreatic neuroendocrine neoplasm and lymphoma present with different features microscopically.

questions.text: 40 years old diabetic male who is a chronic alcoholic, has a history of repeated attacks of severe abdominal pain and back pain since last 8 months. He also gave history of foul smelling diarrhea and progressive weight loss. During the attacks, he gets fever and there is moderate elevation of serum amylase and alkaline phosphatase. CT scan of abdomren shows multiple areas of calcifications in pancreas. Which of the following is correct about the condition he is having?
questions.solution:
the diagnosis of the above case is chronic pancreatitis.

CHRONIC PANCREATITIS:-

  • Prolonged inflammation of the pancreas associated with irreversible destruction of exocrine parenchyma, fibrosis, and, in the late stages, loss of endocrine parenchyma. (Choice A)
  • Most common in - Middle-aged males.
  • Chronic pancreatitis is most often caused by:
    • Repeated bouts of acute pancreatitis
    • Chronic alcohol use
    • Germline mutations in genes such as CFTR (the gene encoding the transporter that is defective in cystic fibrosis), particularly when combined with environmental stressors (choice C)
    • Autoimmune injury (choice B)
  • Clinical features:-
    • Multiple bouts of acute pancreatitis
    • repeated attacks of mild to moderately severe abdominal pain or persistent abdominal and back pain.
    • Attacks may be precipitated by excessive alcohol consumption, overeating (which increases demand on the pancreas), or use of opiates
    • Mild fever
    • mild-to-moderate elevations of serum amylase
  • Microscopy of CHRONIC pancreatitis :- is characterized by parenchymal fibrosis, acinar atrophy and dropout, and variable ductal dilation.
  • Microscopy of ACUTE pancreatitis :- microvascular leak and edema, (2) fat necrosis, (3) acute inflammation, (4) damage, including autodigestion, of pancreatic parenchyma, and (5) blood vessel destruction with interstitial hemorrhage
  • CT/USG abdomen - Visualization of calcifications within the pancreas
  • Microscopy of acute pancreatitis :- microvascular leak and edema, (2) fat necrosis, (3) acute inflammation, (4) damage, including autodigestion, of pancreatic parenchyma, and (5) blood vessel destruction with interstitial hemorrhage

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Chronic Pancreatitis is characterized by irreversible destruction of the exocrine parenchyma, fibrosis, and loss of endocrine tissue in late stages. It is commonly caused by repeated acute pancreatitis, chronic alcohol use, CFTR gene mutations, and autoimmune injury. Key features include repeated abdominal pain, foul-smelling diarrhea, progressive weight loss, and elevated amylase levels. Microscopically, it shows parenchymal fibrosis, acinar atrophy, and ductal dilation, while acute pancreatitis features fat necrosis, microvascular leak, and edema.
